Comment: Before we begin, I should note that both players were playing quite quickly. Not blitz quick, but close to it, often with less than a minute per move.
Ahhh, my beloved Ruy Lopez. Thank you, black! (I don't really know why I like the Ruy so much, but it's been a favorite of mine since I was a kid).
Ahhh, my beloved Ruy Lopez. Thank you, black! (I don't really know why I like the Ruy so much, but it's been a favorite of mine since I was a kid).
Ahhh, my beloved Ruy Lopez. Thank you, black! (I don't really know why I like the Ruy so much, but it's been a favorite of mine since I was a kid).
Ahhh, my beloved Ruy Lopez. Thank you, black! (I don't really know why I like the Ruy so much, but it's been a favorite of mine since I was a kid).
Black chose the Classical (Cordel) Defense. I continue normally, supporting d4.
Black chose the Classical (Cordel) Defense. I continue normally, supporting d4.
Now I win a pawn. Edit: I did not mean to imply that it was forced.
Now I win a pawn. Edit: I did not mean to imply that it was forced.
Black was threatening f7, so I need to protect it.
Black was threatening f7, so I need to protect it.

Black was threatening f7, so I need to protect it.
He is still threatening f7, so I protect it another way, while threatening his knight.
He is still threatening f7, so I protect it another way, while threatening his knight.

8. ... 0-0 was an odd choice I thought. Black could have saved the knight, and my discovered check would have only netted me a pawn. Maybe it was an oversight since we were playing so fast. There seems to be no reprisal, so I eat the knight.

8. ... 0-0 was an odd choice I thought. Black could have saved the knight, and my discovered check would have only netted me a pawn. Maybe it was an oversight since we were playing so fast. There seems to be no reprisal, so I eat the knight.

Thinking that if black exchanges, he can pin and win my e5 pawn by playing a rook to e8. I was afraid of him skewering my queen to my king with Re8, but e8 is not guarded so right now, I would reply with Qxe8 and win the rook. But I have to alleviate this danger very quickly.

Thinking that if black exchanges, he can pin and win my e5 pawn by playing a rook to e8. I was afraid of him skewering my queen to my king with Re8, but e8 is not guarded so right now, I would reply with Qxe8 and win the rook. But I have to alleviate this danger very quickly.

Of course, 11. Pxh3 loses my queen (I could save her by 12. Ne5 and maybe only lose the knight but even that sets up scary discovered attacks). So I ignore the bishop and castle to protect my queen and my g2 pawn. Black has two bishops and queen in striking range of my castled position, which worried me, but I didn't see any attacks that could overcome the defense offered by my queen and knight.

Black sacrifices to open up the castled formation, but again, I don't see an attack that can justify the sacrifice so I take the free bishop.
Black sacrifices to open up the castled formation, but again, I don't see an attack that can justify the sacrifice so I take the free bishop.
The rook move was expected, though I thought it would be the rook on f8 that would attack my queen. My reply offers to trade his most dangerous piece and liquidate toward an easy endgame.
The rook move was expected, though I thought it would be the rook on f8 that would attack my queen. My reply offers to trade his most dangerous piece and liquidate toward an easy endgame.
He accepted my offer and now my King is safe and and white is ahead by two pieces for a pawn.
He accepted my offer and now my King is safe and and white is ahead by two pieces for a pawn.

Shutting down the open e-file that black is more likely to dominate with his better development and also defending my f2 pawn since I am expecting to move my rook out from behind the pawn and don't want it to become a target for black.

Shutting down the open e-file that black is more likely to dominate with his better development and also defending my f2 pawn since I am expecting to move my rook out from behind the pawn and don't want it to become a target for black.

Not my best move. I'm still playing quite fast here, and I wanted to catch up in development. Better was 16. Nf5! which exchanges my weak knight for black's strong bishop. I am also looking at Rg8 and Bxh6 (I have to clear away black's rook from the 6th rank first).

Not my best move. I'm still playing quite fast here, and I wanted to catch up in development. Better was 16. Nf5! which exchanges my weak knight for black's strong bishop. I am also looking at Rg8 and Bxh6 (I have to clear away black's rook from the 6th rank first).

Bad move. I wanted to get my king back into some shelter with Kf1, and I wanted to take the half-open file aimed at black's king. Playing fast, I completely overlooked my hanging knight, allowing black to almost equalize.

Bad move. I wanted to get my king back into some shelter with Kf1, and I wanted to take the half-open file aimed at black's king. Playing fast, I completely overlooked my hanging knight, allowing black to almost equalize.

Well, on the plus side, after my blunder I'm still slightly ahead, thanks to black's questionable sacrifice on his 11th move. We have both given away a free knight this game. Time to be more careful. However, we're both still playing rapidly. With this move I chllenge black on the open e file.

Well, on the plus side, after my blunder I'm still slightly ahead, thanks to black's questionable sacrifice on his 11th move. We have both given away a free knight this game. Time to be more careful. However, we're both still playing rapidly. With this move I chllenge black on the open e file.

By attacking the bishop, I force an exchange of rooks or an exchange of bishops. I'm hoping my tiny material advantage can be exploited to produce a bigger advantage, and liquidiating pieces seems the best approach here.

By attacking the bishop, I force an exchange of rooks or an exchange of bishops. I'm hoping my tiny material advantage can be exploited to produce a bigger advantage, and liquidiating pieces seems the best approach here.
An odd choice by black, trapping his bishop on h4 with nowhere to run. His pawn on g5 cannot recapture because it is pinned. Now black must lose a pawn.
